name: Cascais
tagline: Charming Portuguese Riviera beach town just 30 minutes from Lisbon cruise port

description.short: Cascais is a picturesque seaside town 30km west of Lisbon, known as the Portuguese Riviera. Once a humble fishing village, it transformed into an elegant resort when Portuguese royalty made it their summer residence in the 19th century. Today it offers golden beaches, rugged coastal scenery, charming cobbled streets, and excellent seafood.
description.full: Cascais is a captivating coastal gem that perfectly blends royal elegance with authentic Portuguese charm. Located just 30 kilometers west of Lisbon along the stunning Estoril Coast, this former fishing village rose to prominence in the late 19th century when King Luis I chose it as the royal family's official summer residence. The royal connection transformed Cascais into an exclusive resort destination, attracting European aristocracy and wealthy visitors who built magnificent mansions along its shores. Today, Cascais retains its refined atmosphere while offering something for everyone: pristine beaches with crystal-clear Atlantic waters, dramatic clifftop walks, world-class surfing spots, a charming historic center filled with azulejo-decorated buildings, boutique shopping, art galleries, and outstanding seafood restaurants. The town is famous for its multiple beaches, each with its own character - from the sheltered Praia da Rainha (Queen's Beach) to the wild, wind-swept Guincho Beach popular with surfers. The seafront promenade connects picturesque coves and passes iconic sights like the Santa Marta Lighthouse and the dramatic Boca do Inferno (Mouth of Hell) rock formation. Cascais is incredibly accessible from Lisbon via a scenic 40-minute train ride along the coast, making it the perfect day trip or relaxing beach escape for cruise passengers with limited time.
description.history: Cascais has ancient roots dating back to prehistoric times, with evidence of Roman occupation. For centuries it remained a modest fishing village until 1870 when King Luis I and the Portuguese royal family began spending summers here, transforming it into a fashionable resort. During World War II, Portugal's neutrality made Cascais a haven for European royalty and spies, adding to its cosmopolitan mystique. The town modernized significantly in the 20th century while preserving its historic charm and royal heritage.
description.significance: Cascais represents the perfect accessible beach destination for cruise passengers visiting Lisbon. Its combination of easy accessibility, royal history, stunning coastline, authentic Portuguese culture, and variety of beaches makes it an ideal day trip. The town showcases Portugal's maritime heritage while offering modern amenities and experiences for all types of travelers.

directions.general: Located on the Atlantic coast, 30km west of Lisbon along the Estoril Coast
directions.fromCruisePort: Take train from Cais do Sodre station (10-minute walk from cruise terminal) to Cascais. Trains run every 20 minutes. Journey takes 40 minutes along scenic coastal route.
directions.publicTransport: CP commuter train from Cais do Sodre to Cascais terminus (40 min, €2.30 single). Trains every 20 minutes from 5:30am to 1:30am. Lisboa Card includes this journey. Bus 417 also connects Cascais to Sintra.
directions.parking: Multiple paid parking lots in town center. Free parking available further from center. Limited street parking.

seasonal.hours: 24 hours - beaches and town accessible anytime
seasonal.notes: Beach season typically May-September. Restaurants and shops have individual hours.

admissionPrices.notes: Free to visit town and beaches. Individual attractions (museums, lighthouse) charge separate admission. Train fare from Lisbon: €2.30 single, €4.60 return.

visitingInformation.bestTimeToVisit: May to September for beach weather. September offers warm temperatures with fewer crowds. Spring and fall excellent for sightseeing without summer heat. Weekday visits less crowded than weekends.
visitingInformation.adviceForVisitors: Sit on left side of train from Lisbon for best coastal views. Bring sun protection - limited shade on beaches and coastal walks. Try fresh seafood at harborside restaurants. Walk to Boca do Inferno (15 mins) for dramatic coastal scenery. Visit Santini ice cream parlor - oldest in Portugal. Comfortable walking shoes essential for cobblestone streets. Beach clubs provide loungers and umbrellas for rent. Praia do Guincho (6km north) is spectacular for surfing and scenery.

cruisePassengerInfo.timeNeededFromPort: 5-8 hours for full day experience (includes 1.5 hours round-trip train travel)
cruisePassengerInfo.accessibility: Excellent - easy train access from port area. Town center mostly flat and walkable. Beaches have stairs/access points. Some beach clubs have accessibility features. Coastal walk has uneven surfaces.
tips: Perfect easy day trip - just 40 minutes by scenic coastal train
Purchase Lisboa Card for free train travel to Cascais
Arrive early (9-10am) to maximize beach time
Explore Old Town before or after beach time
Lunch at harbourside seafood restaurants - try fresh grilled fish
Visit Santa Marta Lighthouse and Boca do Inferno rock formation
Praia da Conceicao and Praia da Rainha closest to town center
For surfing, take bus/taxi to Guincho Beach
Try Santini gelato - legendary ice cream since 1949
Train runs late (until 1:30am) allowing dinner in Cascais
Combine with Sintra visit using bus 417

highlights: Multiple beautiful beaches - Praia da Conceicao, Praia da Rainha, Praia da Ribeira
Guincho Beach - world-renowned surfing destination 6km north
Boca do Inferno - dramatic coastal rock formation
Charming Old Town with cobblestone streets and azulejos
Casa de Santa Maria - Italianate waterfront mansion
Parque Marechal Carmona - beautiful gardens and ponds
Museu Condes de Castro Guimaraes - fairytale castle museum
Citadel of Cascais - modern art and cultural space
Scenic coastal promenade and cliff walks
Water sports - surfing, paddleboarding, sailing, jet skiing
facilities: Public restrooms in Parque Marechal Carmona
Free WiFi in some public areas

accessibility.mobilityNotes: Town center relatively flat with some wheelchair-accessible routes. Old Town has cobblestones and hills. Some beaches have accessible ramps (Praia da Conceicao). Beach clubs may have accessibility features. Trains from Lisbon are accessible. Santa Marta Lighthouse not wheelchair accessible. Coastal walks have uneven terrain.
